tutorial.title: Structuring Endpoints
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to build routes that interact with a database

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
GET endpoints in Express allow us to send data requested from our server, making it available to the front end.

Let's explore how to set up and structure GET endpoints with database interactions.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We have a databse.js file to provide us with a database. We'll use it to get the requested data. Give it a quick look before continuing.

Let's start by creating a GET endpoint for /fruits to get all fruits that are in the database.

Make sure to pick app followed by . and then get, "/fruits".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the data in the database, we need to query it.

Create a query and store it in the variable sql.

Make sure to pick const followed by sql and then ", SELECT * FROM fruits, ".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We need to let the database prepare the statement for later use.

Make sure to pick db followed by . and then prepare, sql.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can then execute the statement and retrieve all entries.

Make sure to pick . followed by all and then (, ).

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We want to access the data we get from the database. To do that, we save the returned object in a variable.

Make sure to pick const, followed by fruits, and finally =.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we return the received data as an object with the key "fruits".

Make sure to pick res followed by .status(200) and then .json, fruits: fruits.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the correct status.

Make sure to type 200.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What HTTP status code should we return if our GET endpoint can respond with the requested data?

200 OK201 OK

200 OK.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write an SQL command to select everything from the fruits tablle.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, fruits.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the database connection from the database.js file.

Make sure to pick const followed by db and then =, require, (, "./database.js", ), ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does SELECT * FROM fruits do?

It selects and retrieves all rows and columns from the fruits tableIt selects and retrieves the first row from the fruits table

It selects and retrieves all rows and columns from the fruits table.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've already discussed retrieving all data from a table via a GET endpoint.

Now, we'll create an endpoint that retrieves one specific entry from a database.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We continue to work with our databse.js file, which provides us with a database to work with.

Let's start by setting up a GET endpoint with a route parameter. We'll use that parameter to identify the ID of the fruit that's requested.

Make sure to pick app followed by . and then get, "/fruits/:id".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use a parameterized query with a placeholder for the id.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by id and then =, ?.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we let the database prepare the statement for later use.

Make sure to pick db followed by . and then prepare, sql.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can then execute the statement and pass in the route parameter for the id.

Make sure to pick ., followed by get, and finally req.params.id.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the data we get from the database, we save the returned object in a variable.

Make sure to pick const, followed by fruit, and finally =.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we have a result, we can send back a response, set the status code, and return the object as JSON.

Make sure to pick if followed by fruit and then res, .status(200), .json, fruit: fruit.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we don't get a result, we should return with 404 Not Found and a message.

Make sure to pick else followed by res and then .status(404), .json, message: "Fruit not found".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the correct status code.

Make sure to type 404.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if the item for a given id is not found?

A 404 status should be returnedA 200 status should be returned

A 404 status should be returned.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a parameterized SQL statement that selects the item with a given id from the fruits table.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, fruits, WHERE, id, =, ?.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does res.status(200).json({ fruit: fruit }) do?

It sends a JSON response with a 200 status and the requested fruit object It inserts the fruit into the database

It sends a JSON response with a 200 status and the requested fruit object.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Execute the SQL statement and pass in the route parameter for the id.

Make sure to pick req followed by . and then params, ., id.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is req.params.id used for?

It retrieves the id parameter from the URL (e.g., /fruits/1 retrieves 1) It retrieves the id from the request body

It retrieves the id parameter from the URL (e.g., /fruits/1 retrieves 1).

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've previously covered retrieving data from GET endpoints.

Now, let’s look at how to add new data with a POST endpoint.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We continue to work with our databse.js file, which provides us with a database to work with.

Let's start by setting up a POST endpoint.

Make sure to pick app followed by . and then post, "/fruits".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the data sent in the body, we'll use the built-in Express middleware express.json.

Make sure to pick app, followed by .use, and finally express.json().

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use object destruction to unpack the name property we expect for a new fruit.

Make sure to pick { followed by name and then }, req, .body.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we want to add data to the database, it's important to check if we have what we need.

Check if name is undefined. If so, set the correct status code and return a message explaining what's wrong.

Make sure to pick name followed by === undefined and then 400, "Please provide a name".

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use a parameterized query with a placeholder for the name.

Make sure to pick name, followed by ?.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we let the database prepare the statement for later use.

Make sure to pick db followed by . and then prepare, sql.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can then execute the statement and pass in the unpacked name variable for the name.

Make sure to pick ., followed by run, and finally name.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To ensure the operation has been successful, we save the returned object in a variable.

Make sure to pick const, followed by result, and finally =.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can now check if the insert was successful by evaluating the number of changes made when we check result.changes.

If everything looks good, we can respond, set the status code, and return a message.

Make sure to pick result.changes, followed by > 0, and finally 201.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we don't get a result, we should return with 500 Internal Server Error and a message.

This should be an exception if we have tested all requirements before.

Make sure to pick else, followed by 500, and finally message: "Failed to add fruit".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the correct status code for an unexpected server error.

Make sure to type 500.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
What response should we send if something has been added successfully to the database?

201 OK200 OK

201 OK.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the correct status code for a successful insert of the new element.

Make sure to type 201.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does result.changes > 0 check for?

It checks if a row was successfully inserted into the databaseIt checks if the name was updated successfully

It checks if a row was successfully inserted into the database.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a parameterized SQL statement that inserts the item with a given name into the fruits table.

Make sure to pick INSERT followed by INTO and then fruits, (name), VALUES, (?).

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll now take a look at DELETE and PATCH endpoints.

We continue to work with our databse.js file, which provides us with a database to work with.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When creating a DELETE endpoint, we need to check the route parameter to understand what entry should be deleted.

Make sure to pick :id, followed by id, and finally req.params.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use a parameterized query with a placeholder for the id. After preparing the statement, we can run it and pass the route parameter.

Make sure to pick DELETE followed by id and then ?, id.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
We haven't checked if id was actually a valid value. We'll now check the result and see if everything worked out.

We check the number of changes by looking at result.changes, and send back a fitting response.

Make sure to pick result.changes > 0, followed by 200, and finally 404.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to the DELETE endpoint, when creating a PATCH endpoint, we need to unpack the route parameter.

Make sure to pick :, followed by id, and finally id.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the data sent in the body, we'll use the built-in Express middleware express.json.

Once we have added the middleware, we can access the body.

Make sure to pick app.use, followed by express.json(), and finally req.body.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We need to check if we've received all the data before proceeding. If something is missing that we need, we send back 400 Bad Request.

Make sure to pick !name, followed by 400.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Again, we use a parameterized query with placeholders. After preparing the statement, we can run it and pass the needed parameters.

We need to ensure the parameters are in the right order.

Make sure to pick !name followed by 400 and then UPDATE fruits, SET name = ?, WHERE id = ?, name, id.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
And similar to what we've seen before, we check result.changes to identify what status code and message we should return.

Make sure to pick result.changes > 0, followed by 200, and finally 404.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the appropriate status code.

Make sure to type 404.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the fitting status code.

Make sure to type 200.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
What should happen if no item with the given id is found when trying to delete it?

A 404 status should be returnedA 500 status should be returned

A 404 status should be returned.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Check if the database operation was a success.

Make sure to pick result followed by . and then changes, >, 0.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a parameterized SQL statement that updates an item’s name based on a given id.

Make sure to pick "UPDATE followed by fruits and then SET, name, =, ?, WHERE, id, =, ?.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy  - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if the name is not provided in the request body when updating a fruit?

A 400 status is returned with the message "Please provide a name"A 404 status is returned with the message "Fruit not found"

A 400 status is returned with the message "Please provide a name".
